billsco

For those of us who have great difficulty believing we evolved from apes, here's a story you may want to first sit down before reading, because it explains that we evolved from fish. At least our inner ear did--from an ancient fish's gill. I know, the monkey thing is hard to swallow, bad medicine and all, but I'm kind of excited to know my cousin is a crappie. 
 
 http://news.softpedia.com/news/Did-our-ancestors-breathe-through-their-ears-16611.shtml

There isn't anything controversial about the articles claims, it has long been recognised that mammals evolved from reptile stock, who where descended from amphibians whose ancestors where fish.

billsco

There isn't anything controversial about the articles claims, it has long been recognised that mammals evolved from reptile stock, who where descended from amphibians whose ancestors where fish.

 
 Could not this discovery (or observation) be viewed as a missing link?
trebor

Could not this discovery (or observation) be viewed as a missing link?

 
 
 No, since the concept of a 'missing link' is not really valid. The observation could just be considered the path that was followed, rather than a 'missing link'.
sinjin
So, what else is new? Think it's a coincidence that fish have two eyes?
OccamsRazor

Could not this discovery (or observation) be viewed as a missing link?

 
 I'd more describe it in terms like trebor's. It is a very interesting find though, and it adds more knowledge to our understanding of how the ear formed. From "our" point of view (as mammals) it shows how the original land vertebrate ear developed and we can then see how further modification over time (the development of the mammalian jaw) lead to the development of the mammalian ear with its three bones- an excellent example of how evolution works by modifying existing structures into new forms.
prschuster

I'd more describe it in terms like trebor's. It is a very interesting find though, and it adds more knowledge to our understanding of how the ear formed. From "our" point of view (as mammals) it shows how the original land vertebrate ear developed and we can then see how further modification over time (the development of the mammalian jaw) lead to the development of the mammalian ear with its three bones- an excellent example of how evolution works by modifying existing structures into new forms.

 
 
 Walking-fish:
 It's certainly a more exciting detective story than the 6-day creation myth. Speaking of which, I onced asked a creationist what day God made Ichthyostega? Was it on the 5th day with the fish or the 6th day with the land animals, or was He so confused that He made these walking fish at the stroke of midnight? I never could get an answer from a YEC about this. Maybe I'll ask "Answers In Genesis".

thelmoose

I hope everyone knows that human embryos have gills for a time. Is that an intelligent design?
 
 Ontogeny Recapitulates Phylogeny!!
prschuster

I hope everyone knows that human embryos have gills for a time. Is that an intelligent design?
 
 Ontogeny Recapitulates Phylogeny!!

 
 
 
 
 Walking-fish:
 I would be careful about making statements like that around a seasoned creationist, or else you may be skewered on your own petard. They will point out that the pharyngeal pouches never break through to become true "gill slits" in human embryos. They will also give you a lecture about Haeckel's "faked drawings", and explain that all of the evolutionary stages are NOT recapitulated in ontogeny as Haeckel's Law states. They will do this in order to give the impression that there is absolutely no evidence for evolution in embryology.
 
 But there is plenty of evidence, and this fact can be pointed out by explaining how modified versions of embryonic stages are recapitulated, rather than an idealized, unmodified recapitulation of the adult ancestors. There is still a lot that can be explained, however, such as the exaptation of the first pharyngeal arch for the jaw, or the reduction of the 6 Aortic arches to be fashioned into three pair of arteries (Aorta / Pulmonary / Carotid), or the long course of the Recurrent Laryngeal nerve. I have yet to see a creationist refute the evolutionary implications of these developments.
pandion

I hope everyone knows that human embryos have gills for a time.
No they don't. Where did you ever hear that? All mammalian embryos, humans included, have pharyngeal pouches for a time. They are separated by aortic arches. These structures develop into the gill arches in fish, but in other organisms they never do. They have been called "gill slits" because of their similiarity to the structures in fish embryos that develop into gills. But they never, ever form gills in mammals.
 
Is that an intelligent design?
I think that the question is moot.
 
Ontogeny Recapitulates Phylogeny!!
Ah! I remember that phrase with some fondness and nostalgia. Way back in my undergraduate days, on the first day of my embryology class the professor wrote it on the board. He stepped to the front of the class, pointed to it and declared that if anyone ever began to accept that statement as correct, they should see him immediately for correction, as that person would be in imminent danger of failing the course.
thelmoose

No they don't. Where did you ever hear that? All mammalian embryos, humans included, have pharyngeal pouches for a time. They are separated by aortic arches. These structures develop into the gill arches in fish, but in other organisms they never do. They have been called "gill slits" because of their similiarity to the structures in fish embryos that develop into gills. But they never, ever form gills in mammals.
 I think that the question is moot.
 Ah! I remember that phrase with some fondness and nostalgia. Way back in my undergraduate days, on the first day of my embryology class the professor wrote it on the board. He stepped to the front of the class, pointed to it and declared that if anyone ever began to accept that statement as correct, they should see him immediately for correction, as that person would be in imminent danger of failing the course.

 
 Thank you for the clarification. I made the statement in a playful way because of the fish in the ear theme. I did know that actual gills do not form. I stand completely corrected. You are also astute to point out the undergrad embryo class as the I heard the phrase. Again, the edification is appreciated.
